column3:
Level 1:
Basic Basic awareness and foundational knowledge. Requires close supervision and detailed guidance.
column4:
Level 2:
Intermediate Working knowledge and consistent application. Needs periodic supervision and support for complex tasks.
column5:
Level 3:
Advanced Comprehensive understanding and independent application. Can handle most complex situations and guide others.
column6:
Level 4:
Expert Complete mastery, innovation, and leadership. Sets standards, develops new approaches, and mentors others.

column1: Functional Skills: technical or job-related skills that are necessary to perform tasks within a particular role
column3: Candidate struggles with fundamental database concepts, unable to define primary/foreign keys, identify correct table relationships (e.g., one-to-many vs. many-to-many), or apply basic normalization principles (e.g., repeating groups). May propose designs with significant data redundancy or lack clear entity relationships. Requires constant guidance for even simple schema tasks.
column4: Candidate can design functional schemas for straightforward problems, but often overlooks critical details such as appropriate data types, effective indexing for performance, or proper handling of null values. Shows limited understanding of the impact of schema changes on existing systems and may lack robust strategies for safe database migrations (e.g., transaction management, rollback plans).
column5: Candidate designs correct and well-structured schemas, demonstrating a solid understanding of data modeling, relationships, and normalization. Considers the implications of schema changes and proposes some effective strategies for migrations, including understanding the need for backward compatibility or using basic schema versioning. Can optimize designs for specific use cases (e.g., read-heavy systems) and articulate trade-offs.
column6: Candidate demonstrates complete mastery of database design principles, creating robust, scalable, and highly performant architectures. Consistently accounts for complex edge cases (e.g., large data volumes, concurrent access, distributed systems), and develops comprehensive, safe production migration plans that include detailed steps, monitoring, and contingency plans. Designs for high availability, disaster recovery, and advanced indexing techniques. Acts as a mentor and sets best practices.

column3: Candidate struggles with basic diagnostic steps, relies entirely on guesswork, or panics when encountering errors. Fails to use logs or monitoring effectively and is unable to articulate the steps taken or the root cause of an issue. Requires constant supervision to resolve even simple, pre-identified issues.
column4: Candidate can follow a prescribed troubleshooting guide or checklist for known issues but struggles with novel or complex problems. They can identify symptoms but often misdiagnose the root cause. Requires periodic support for deep dives and may take an inefficient, trial-and-error approach to resolution.
column5: Candidate employs a systematic, logical approach to diagnosing and resolving a wide range of issues, including novel ones. They effectively use monitoring tools and logs to pinpoint the root cause and propose robust, long-term solutions. Can work independently on complex problems, only escalating when necessary.
column6: Candidate is an expert diagnostician who anticipates failure modes and designs systems with observability in mind. They can resolve critical production incidents under extreme pressure, rapidly isolate issues in unfamiliar systems, and lead post-mortems that drive systemic, preventative architectural changes.

column3: Candidate struggles to articulate the overall structure or components of a simple system. Proposes monolithic designs without considering common architectural patterns, scalability, security, or trade-offs (e.g., synchronous vs. asynchronous). Requires substantial guidance to draft a basic architecture diagram.
column4: Candidate can design functional systems for a defined, small-scale problem, but often defaults to familiar patterns without critical justification. They may overlook critical non-functional requirements (e.g., effective monitoring, fault tolerance, cost). Requires periodic support to make critical architectural trade-offs or to design for future growth.
column5: Candidate designs well-structured, scalable systems, effectively applying appropriate architectural patterns (e.g., microservices, event-driven). They can clearly articulate trade-offs, address non-functional requirements, and justify technology choices. Can independently design a system for a moderately complex domain.
column6: Candidate demonstrates complete mastery, designing robust, globally scalable, and highly available architectures that anticipate future needs and organizational growth. They lead the design of complex, cross-functional systems, set architectural standards, and mentor others. Proactively identifies and mitigates long-term technical debt and risk.

column1:
Practices: 
specific methods, techniques, or processes to achieve specific goals
Business Impact: skills that influence on the overall success and strategic direction of the organization
column3: Provides a reactive or theoretical answer with no initiative, analysis, or example outside normal duties.
column4: Noticed a smaller issue and contributed to fixing it, but impact was limited, tactical, or shared.
column5: Identified a meaningful problem, led a solid fix, used reasonable analysis, and produced a local improvement.
column6: Identified a significant issue early, analyzed it deeply, owned the full solution, and drove measurable impact.

column3: Fails to communicate the technical challenge clearly; explanation is confusing, overly technical, or missing key information.
column4: Shows basic communication ability, but explanations are overly detailed, unstructured, or hard to follow.
column5: Explains a complex technical challenge clearly and logically, with only occasional over-detailing.
column6: Communicates complex technical issues in a structured, accessible way; shows mastery through clarity and audience adaptation.

column3:
A:Shows poor teamwork: blame, conflict avoidance, negative attitude, lack of communication, and no ownership of team outcomes.

B:Prioritizes I over we. Passively contributes in teamwork. Blames others, avoids conflict, poor communication, and does not take ownership for team outcomes. Does not contribute to collective success.

R: Only talks about "I" never "we", IS very passive in the team, only does what they're asked to do. Poor communication in general
column4:
Participates in teamwork but does not actively strengthen it. Cooperation is adequate but not proactive; limited contribution to resolving conflict or improving cohesion.


B:Participates in teamwork but mostly focuses on individual tasks. Helps when asked but does not actively strengthen team unity. Limited effort in resolving issues or creating shared understanding.

R: Mainly talks about "I" never "we", Is mostly passive in the team, only does what they're asked to do. Comm is not great
column5:
Works well with others, communicates clearly, and contributes to team alignment. Handles challenges constructively, even if not shaping team dynamics at a high level.

B:Works well with others and communicates clearly. Thinks about “we” not just “I.” Helps align the team, supports shared goals, and contributes to a constructive working environment.

R: Talks about "we" rarely "I", An active team member, Good communication in general
column6:
Actively elevates team cohesion, resolves conflict, keeps the group aligned, and improves team performance—even in a difficult project. A true team player.

B:Actively builds strong team cohesion. Brings people together, resolves conflicts constructively, and keeps everyone aligned on shared goals. Drives lasting, team-wide solutions and elevates overall team performance. Truly team-first.

R: Knows when to work with the team and when to handle tasks alone., Is veru active in the team. Good communication

column3: Struggles with change. Negative attitude, no growth, and poor performance under pressure.
column4: Can deal with change, but not smoothly. Needs support and learns only a little.
column5: Handles change well. Stays productive and learns, even if not leading others through the change.
column6: Handles change very well. Fast, calm, and helpful to others. Learns and improves from hard situations.

column3: Struggles to learn new skills. Slow, resistant, and unable to apply new knowledge. Little or no growth.
column4: Learns with support but not quickly. Application is inconsistent. Limited improvement from the experience.
column5: Learns well and can become productive quickly. Shows good curiosity and some repeatable learning habits.
column6: Learns extremely fast with little help. Applies new knowledge right away. Improves future work with strong learning habits.

column1: Business Impact: skills that influence on the overall success and strategic direction of the organization
column3: Avoids responsibility, lacks follow-through, frequently misses deadlines, and needs constant supervision.
column4: Takes responsibility but requires frequent reminders, struggles to work autonomously, and does not proactively solve issues.
column5: Reliable, ensures follow-through on tasks, takes initiative when needed, and delivers assigned work on time.
column6: Takes full ownership, proactively drives solutions, aligns with stakeholders, and removes blockers for the team.

column2: TECHNICAL CRITICAL THINKING (Code Quality & System Design)
column3: Struggles to analyze and resolve problems, frequently introduces new bugs, requires constant guidance for debugging and troubleshooting.
column4: Solves basic problems but lacks independent thinking, often applies quick fixes without addressing root causes.
column5: Strong analytical thinker, resolves most issues independently, applies structured problem-solving approaches.
column6: Proactively identifies potential issues, optimizes solutions, and improves system performance with minimal oversight.

column2: TECHNICAL CRITICAL THINKING (Code Quality & System Design)
column3: Weak technical skills, struggles with engineering fundamentals, writes inefficient or error-prone code, and frequently needs rework.
column4: Has a basic understanding of technical concepts but needs guidance for complex tasks, occasionally writes suboptimal or unscalable code.
column5: Strong technical skills, writes clean, maintainable, and efficient code, follows best practices, and designs robust solutions.
column6: Highly skilled in writing optimized, scalable, and secure code. Refactors and improves existing codebases, mentors others on best practices, and actively participates in system design discussions.

column3: Slow execution, struggles to complete tasks on time, resists adopting new technologies, and frequently fails to adjust to changing project needs. Often overwhelmed under pressure.
column4: Manages workload but struggles with adaptability, requires significant guidance to pick up new tools or frameworks, and has difficulty handling unexpected challenges.
column5: Works efficiently, balances speed and quality, adapts well to new technologies, and can adjust workflows when priorities shift. Handles pressure in a steady manner.
column6: Quickly learns and integrates new tools and frameworks, efficiently refactors code to improve performance, and remains highly productive even in high-pressure situations.

column2: Fast Learner to be added by Rads
